messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@b...> wrote:
> > the assert:
> > - can not be ignored (exception can be ignored via emtpy try
catch
> > block)
>
>
> Warning! the assert keyword may _not_ be evaluated. Sun sugests
to run
> the Java application without the "assert" option to increase
speed. So
> you cannot be sure that your application will _always_ run in the
> 'assert' mode. Using the _optional_ 'assert' mode to validate
something
> that is _not_ optional (parameter's value) is IMO a big mistake.
>
> > the exception:
> > - is more explicit (IllegalArgument tells me the exact problem)
> > - better communicated in docs (javadoc picks it up, hopefully
this
> > will change for assertions one day)
>
>
> if (n < 0)
> throw new IllegalArgumentException("blah");
>
> if (n < 0) the exception will _always_ be thrown
>
>
> > But at the end of the day they the look the same to me - just
> > different in implementation.
>
>
> absolutely not, because at the end of the day you can run your
program
> without evaluating the assert keyword and you don't control
anything
> anymore. This is a _big_ difference.
>
> My point is that an _optional_ assertion mechanism ("assert"
keyword)
> cannot replace a _non-optional_ error-reporting mechanism
(exceptions).
> They may be complementary (still not convinced by 'assert').
>
> Or am I missing the point?
>
> -Vladimir
>

Great points Vlad. I agree that the big difference is that one can
be turned off while the other one can not.

It seems to me assertions are best used as an internal mechanism for
enforing a contract within a class. A helpful tool for developers
when they are developing.

The exception on the other hand is there to stand the test of time
and always be on. Good for bullet proofing the code.

I believe assertions should be used more sparingly then exceptions
(like IllegalArgumentException).

Thx to everyone who contributed on this thread. I can put my mind
slightly more at ease now with the feedback you have given.

Cheers

Jonathan
